narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned a great deal about the history of television.
I learned a lot about television history, the kinds of social influences that impact television as well as the industry, and lot of scholarly theory surrounding the format.

Professor Shechtman's curriculum was very thorough and covered every aspect from the inception of television as we know it, the theories surrounding television's rise in the home, the history and narrative around representation in television and the rise of subscription based streaming services.

This course was basically a survey of the history of television (mostly in the US) mostly in terms of the social development and implications surrounding TV and more modern media. Topics specifically included some theory about TV as a medium, race and gender on TV, the theoretical "flow" of TV, the transition from the TV set to streaming online, and more.
The history of television and the processes that have shaped and continue to shape it.
Looking at the evolution of an everyday product in a critical way.

AMAZING appreciation for the history of TV as much more than merely an aesthetic medium. An ability to apply scholarly frameworks to the things that we watch on a day to day basis and understand why they have persisted. Prof. Shechtman also provides very detailed feedback on papers and argument construction, which is very helpful.
I gained a greater understanding of television as a medium, as well as learned about televisions influence on class divisions, social movements, and pop culture.
history of television in the U.S., theories about the role of television in society, writing about media studies
A broad overview of television theory and history

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Every part of this course was done pretty well I would say. The required screenings were all interesting and well-placed within our discussions.

Most days we would struggle to cover both of the days readings throughly and therefore I think it would have been valuable to focus more closely on just one reading a day. Furthermore, I believe it would have been helpful to go over the desired format for the essays more heavily to make the prompts and instructions clearer.

We watched some great example episodes and clips to give context for the theory we were learning and Professor Shechtman always worked hard to make clear exactly what in our often convoluted readings was important. We also always had good conversation because the topic lent itself well to personal anecdotes. One weakness, already semi-mentioned, is that the readings were pretty convoluted VERY DENSE. It was often hard to figure out what exactly we should be getting from the text and how it related to the screenings for the week. We also often did in-class activities that involved doing a lot of complicated textual analysis in a very short amount of time and then having to present informally on the spot for our classmates. I found these activities quite challenging and rarely felt like I got much out of the text in that context.

Learning about the history of television and how its come to be was really fun and interesting. All I could think of to improve the course would be more tv episodes from a particular series, maybe watching a whole miniseries or something along those lines.
Strength is getting many different views on the same topic

It is unbelievable. Prof. Shechtman is such an expert about the material and it is a topic/field that everyone loves in their own ways. There is so much of an opportunity to interact with classmates, too, each of whom has a different personal relationship with television.

The strength of this course comes from the discussions we had about the materials we viewed and read. Another strength comes from how interconnected television is; allowing us to explore the influence of television closely.
strenght: professor is young and able to explain the material in an interesting and relevant way
I appreciated the teaching style and discussions, but I would had liked to watch and analyze more film during class time.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The flexible deadlines were very helpful and allowed me to not stress too much about the class.

Seminars are hard on zoom... it's challenging to get a good class dynamic and even more challenging to get a good flow of conversation. This class did as good a job at it as I think you can. Good use of breakout rooms for smaller discussion. Screen sharing and shared docs were used effectively.
There is only so much one can do with virtual classes. The class integrated technology nicely, but thats really it.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! This class is so fun, and the material is really interesting.
Definitely, especially if you like television.
Yes, this course is a great course for film majors but would also be a great course for a writing credit. The workload is not that heavy and the topics are deeply interesting if you enjoy media.

If you're interested in television theory (not just interested in television generally) then absolutely. If you love TV for exactly what it is and aren't interested in more nuanced analysis then I'm not sure you'll enjoy it as much as you think.
Yes! Especially if you are interested in television and the processes that have shaped it
Yes, this is a great course
Highly. Take it. You will love it. I guarantee you.
I would. This class is a great introduction to thinking critically about television, as well as a great introduction to theories of film and technologies.
yes, if you are interested in theory and history
Yes definitely! This was my first film class and I found it interesting, engaging, and a great introduction into learning about media.
Yes, if you are interested at all in American culture or media theory, this is an amazing course.
